articles.headline: Olmert Memoir Cites Near Deal for Mideast Peace
articles.snippet: Former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel says Mahmoud Abbas’s hesitation, his own legal troubles and the war in Gaza scotched a potential deal in late 2008.
articles.abstract: Former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel says Mahmoud Abbas’s hesitation, his own legal troubles and the war in Gaza scotched a potential deal in late 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel, says in new memoirs that he and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, were very close to a peace deal two years ago, but Mr. Abbas’s hesitation, Mr. Olmert’s own legal troubles and the Israeli war in Gaza caused their talks to end. Shortly afterward, a right-wing Israeli government came to power.

articles.headline: For Housing, a Quick Fix 0r Less Risk
articles.snippet: Pruning Fannie and Freddie could be disruptive, but less so if the shift back to private sector mortgage insurance happened gradually.
articles.abstract: Pruning Fannie and Freddie could be disruptive, but less so if the shift back to private sector mortgage insurance happened gradually.
articles.lead_paragraph: What can be done with Frannie? We love her and we need her. But we have to get along without her, or at least learn to live without relying on her so much.

articles.headline: U.S. Approves Genetically Modified Alfalfa
articles.snippet: The agriculture secretary pulled back from a proposal that would have restricted the growing of genetically engineered alfalfa to protect organic farmers.
articles.abstract: The agriculture secretary pulled back from a proposal that would have restricted the growing of genetically engineered alfalfa to protect organic farmers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced on Thursday that he would authorize the unrestricted commercial cultivation of genetically modified alfalfa, setting aside a controversial compromise that had generated stiff opposition.

articles.headline: U.S. Company, in Reversal, Wants to Export Natural Gas
articles.snippet: Charif Souki, chief of Cheniere Energy, envisions a network of terminals exporting cheap American natural gas to Europe and Asia.
articles.abstract: Charif Souki, chief of Cheniere Energy, envisions a network of terminals exporting cheap American natural gas to Europe and Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMERON PARISH, La.  The oil patch is a world of risk takers, but few are as daring as Charif Souki, the chairman and chief executive of Cheniere Energy.

articles.headline: Court Allows Emanuel on Ballot for Chicago Mayor
articles.snippet: Rahm Emanuel’s bid to become Chicago’s mayor may proceed, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled.
articles.abstract: Rahm Emanuel’s bid to become Chicago’s mayor may proceed, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel’s bid to become mayor of this city may proceed, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled on Thursday, ending a week that had turned this city’s politics upside down, then back again.

articles.headline: In Japan, Young Face Generational Roadblocks
articles.snippet: Japan’s economy is clogged with aging vested interests, frustrating the young people needed to maintain its edge.
articles.abstract: Japan’s economy is clogged with aging vested interests, frustrating the young people needed to maintain its edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Kenichi Horie was a promising auto engineer, exactly the sort of youthful talent Japan needs to maintain its edge over hungry Korean and Chinese rivals. As a worker in his early 30s at a major carmaker, Mr. Horie won praise for his design work on advanced biofuel systems.

articles.headline: Cables Show Delicate U.S. Dealings With Egypt’s Leaders
articles.snippet: A trove of dispatches made public by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks paint a vivid picture of the delicate dealings between the United States and Egypt.
articles.abstract: A trove of dispatches made public by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks paint a vivid picture of the delicate dealings between the United States and Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first meeting as secretary of state with President Hosni Mubarak, in March 2009, and the Egyptians had an odd request: Mrs. Clinton should not thank Mr. Mubarak for releasing an opposition leader from prison because he was ill.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Seizing a Moment, Al Jazeera Galvanizes Arab Frustration
articles.snippet: The channel has helped shape a narrative of popular rage against oppressive American-backed Arab governments.
articles.abstract: The channel has helped shape a narrative of popular rage against oppressive American-backed Arab governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The protests rocking the Arab world this week have one thread uniting them: Al Jazeera, the Qatar-based satellite channel whose aggressive coverage has helped propel insurgent emotions from one capital to the next.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Waves of Unrest Spread to Yemen, Shaking a Region
articles.snippet: Thousands protested in Yemen and secular and Islamist Egyptian opposition leaders vowed to join rallies as calls for change rang across the Arab world.
articles.abstract: Thousands protested in Yemen and secular and Islamist Egyptian opposition leaders vowed to join rallies as calls for change rang across the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters on Thursday took to the streets of Yemen, one of the Middle East’s most impoverished countries, and secular and Islamist Egyptian opposition leaders vowed to join large protests expected Friday as calls for change rang across the Arab world.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid, Nada Bakri and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Mubarak Orders Crackdown, With Revolt Sweeping Egypt
articles.snippet: Protesters continued to defy a nationwide curfew early Saturday as President Hosni Mubarak deployed the military to save his authoritarian government of nearly 30 years.
articles.abstract: Protesters continued to defy a nationwide curfew early Saturday as President Hosni Mubarak deployed the military to save his authoritarian government of nearly 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  With police stations and the governing party’s headquarters in flames, and much of this crucial Middle Eastern nation in open revolt, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt deployed the nation’s military and imposed a near-total blackout on communications to save his authoritarian government of nearly 30 years.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 3.2% Rate in the 4th Quarter
articles.snippet: The number, slightly below analysts’ expectations, reflected a sharp rise in consumer spending.
articles.abstract: The number, slightly below analysts’ expectations, reflected a sharp rise in consumer spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a little more money in their wallets and a little less fear in their hearts, American consumers helped pull the economy up by its bootstraps in the final months of last year.
